Additionally, there is a satellite lesion that is 0.7 cm in size, located 2 cm superior to the index mass. However, for T staging, only the size of the largest tumor is considered. The report also mentions that the tumor is an invasive ductal carcinoma, and the T stage is determined by the size of the largest tumor, ignoring any substaging information. Therefore, the T stage for this patient is T1c.

humanMachineDialogue.text: The patient has an invasive ductal carcinoma with a largest contiguous size of the tumor (G) of 2.0 cm and an additional satellite lesion that is 0.7 cm, making the total size of the tumor (T) 2.7 cm. According to the 7th edition of the AJCC cancer staging manual, a T1 tumor is any tumor that is 2 cm or less in size, and T1c is used when the tumor is more than 1 cm but not more than 2 cm in size with extensive intraductal component (EIC). However, in this case, the report does not mention anything about EIC. Therefore, based only on the size of the tumor, the T stage would be T1c.
